Problem:
Consider a function \\( u(x, t) \\) describing heat distribution along a rod governed by the heat equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k\\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2} \\) with constant diffusivity k. Investigate the implications of the Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} u(x, t)e^{-i\\omega x}dx \\) applied to this model.

If an intervention applies a filtering function \\( g(\\omega) \\) modifying \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, t) \\) at time t_1, will the solution at time T, \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\), be solely decided by the heat equation ignoring the effects of \\( g(\\omega) \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with the filtering function \\( g(\\omega) \\) alters the spectral components of \\( u(x, t) \\), thereby changing the outcome \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\). Thus, \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\) depends not only on the heat equation but also critically on the filter applied, impacting diffusion characteristics across frequencies.
